choices.text: Flush ligation of SFJ with stripping of vein

questions.text: In a patient with symptomatic varicose veins where the GSV has reflux and a diameter of 9mm, the preferred surgical treatment is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B: RFA (radiofrequency ablation) is the best method to manage symptomatic varicose vein patients. EVLT (endovenous laser therapy) is equally effective as RFA in the management of these patients Option A: Sclerotherapy is used for patients with veins less than 3 mm in diameter and this technique is associated with a lot of complications Option D: Open surgery (Trendelenburg procedure) – flush ligation of SFJ was done earlier but since the development of RFA/EVLT, this is not used.

questions.text: Pulmonary Thromboembolism after is usually from which veins:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Most common site of DVT which leads to thromboembolism is femoropopliteal veins Most common site of DVT overall is Calf veins.

questions.text: All of the following are congenital cause of DVT except ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Deep vein thrombosis occurs most commonly after:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: DVT, investigation of choice is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Investigation of choice for diagnosis of DVT is doppler(Filling defects in flow and lack of compressibility indicate the presence of a thrombosis). Option B. Plethysmography can help but is neither sensitive nor specific to diagnose DVT. Option C. Venography can be done but is an invasive procedure. Option D. Can be used as a screening test but the best investigation to diagnose DVT is duplex scan or doppler study.

questions.text: For prophylaxis of deep vein thrombosis not used is: (PGI 2007)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) We do not use warfarin as a prophylactic measure for DVT instead we use heparin for prophylaxis.

questions.text: Earliest sign of DVT is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Earliest sign of DVT is calf tenderness . Options B and C. Rise in local temperature and swelling in calf muscles are also the features of DVT but they occur late. Option D. Homan’s sign:It is an increased resistance to passive dorsiflexion of foot. It is a clinical examination finding of DVT. It appears late in the disease process and not advisable to do as it increases the chance of thromboembolism. Moses sign : Pain occurs when calf is squeezed

questions.text: White leg is due to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: The minimum duration of heparin therapy in deep vein thrombosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Heparin is given for treatment of DVT at least for 7 days Warfarin is started at the dose of 10 mg on day one, 10 mg on day two and 5 mg on day three. PT-INR report on day three guides the maintenance dose of warfarin. Minimum treatment time for anticoagulation advocated in DVT is 3 months.

choices.text: 45 year old male with first episode of DVT
80 year old male with first episode of DVT
55 year old male with recent history of intracranial haemorrhage with DVT
50 year old female with DVT in the postpartum period

questions.text: Which one of the following is an indication for IVC filter in a patient with DVT?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Indications for IVC filter in patients with DVT 1. Recurrent DVT despite anticoagulation 2. Contraindication for anticoagulation in a patient with proximal DVT 3. Recurrent pulmonary embolisms despite anticoagulation The commonly used filter is a kimray Greenfield filter.

questions.text: Device which has been shown in the figure is used for which condition ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pneumatic compression device provide Intermittent pneumatic compression which is a therapeutic technique that include an air pump and inflatable auxiliary sleeves, gloves or boots in a system designed to improve venous circulation in the limbs of patients who suffer edema or the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE) . An inflatable jacket (sleeve, glove or boot) encloses the limb requiring treatment, and pressure lines are connected between the jacket and the air pump. When activated, the pump fills the air chambers of the jacket in order to pressurize the tissues in the limb, thereby forcing fluids, such as blood and lymph, out of the pressurized area. A short time later, the pressure is reduced, allowing increased blood flow back into the limb. The primary functional aim of the device “is to squeeze blood from the underlying deep veins, which, assuming that the valves are competent, will be displaced proximally.” When the inflatable sleeves deflate, the veins will replenish with blood. The intermittent compressions of the sleeves will ensure the movement of venous blood.

choices.text: Most common clinically presents as pain and tenderness
Some cases may directly present as pulmonary thromboembolism

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct about Deep Venous thrombosis except ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B. Most of the patients of DVT are unilateral. Only 30 % of the patients of DVT are bilateral . Option A. Option A is correct as clinical assessment is highly reliable for diagnosing DVT. Option C. Most common clinical presentation of DVT is calf tenderness. Option D. Pulmonary embolism is a dreaded complication of DVT and patients may present with pulmonary embolism .

questions.text: Patient had a retrograde pelvic thrombophlebitis and it progressed to bilateral iliofemoral occlusion and now the presentation is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In this question patient has bilateral iliofemoral occlusion. So complete venous drainage of lower limbs is occluded and so patients present with painful blue leg . Option B. Painful white occurs when patient develops occlusion of only the deep venous system. In this condition venous drainage is still continued by collateral circulation and superficial veins.

questions.text: Varicose veins of size less than_____can be best treated by sclerotherapy:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sclerotherapy is useful for dealing with minor varicosities (<3mm) and recurrence in calf and lower leg. Amount of sclerosant used in treatment of varicose vein is 0.5 ml. “Varicose veins: sclerotherapy”:- • Sodium tetra-decylsulphate is most commonly used. • It causes thrombosis, fibrosis and sclerosis by destroying lipid membrane of endothelial cells. • Not good for major saphenous incompetenece. • Only suitable for below knee varicose veins. • Need to exclude SFJ or SPJ incompetence • Main use is for persistent or recurrent varicose veins after adequate saphenous surgery. • Sclerosants:- 5% Ethanolamine oleate or 0.5% Sodium tetradecylsulphate (Most commonly used). • Needle placed in vein when full with patient standing. • Empty vein prior to injection. • Apply immediate compression and maintain for 4-6 weeks. Complications of sclerotherapy:- • Extravasation causing pigmentation or ulceration. • Deep venous thrombosis.

questions.text: Drug used for sclerotherapy of varicose veins are the following except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Sclerosing Agents Are :- Phenol (5%) in almond oil or peanut oil Ethanolamine oleate (5%) in 25% glycerin and 2% benzyl alcohol Polidocanol (3%) Sodium tetradecyl sulphate (3%) with benzyl alcohol (2%) Hypertonic saline

questions.text: Brodie-Trendelenburg test is positive in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The Trendelenburg test is used to determine the site of valvular incompetence in a patient with varicose veins. Ask the patient to lie down. Elevate the leg, and empty the veins by massaging distal to proximal. Using a tourniquet, occlude the superficial veins in the upper thigh. Ask the patient to stand. If the tourniquet prevents the veins from re-filling rapidly, the site of the incompetent valve must be above this level i.e. at the saphenofemoral junction. If the veins refill, the communication must be lower down. Observing the same protocol, proceed down the leg until the tourniquet controls re-filling. As necessary, test: 1. above the knee - to assess the mid-thigh perforator 2. below the knee - to assess competence between the short saphenous vein and popliteal vein

choices.text: Biopsy should be taken from chronic ulcer

questions.text: All are true about varicose ulcer except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) We do not perform varicose vein stripping for every case of Varicose ulcer. We need to manage it with compression bandage and leg elevation. Option B. In all cases of Varicose vein we must rule out DVT. Because if DVT is present then stripping of the varicose vein is contraindicated and as it will lead to venous gangrene. Option C. Biopsy should be taken from all chronic non healing ulcers to rule out malignancy. Malignancy developing in chronic non healing ulcer is low grade SCC. Option D. Klippel trenaunay syndrome is associated with, varicose vein, limb hypertrophy, cutaneous birthmarks (Port Wine Stain) and deep venous system is anomalous or absent.

questions.text: Cocket and Dodd operation is for:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cockett and Dodd Operation: Subfascial ligation of perforators. Option A. Operative procedure for varicose vein is trendelenburg's operation. Trendelenburg's operation consists of subfascial ligation of the saphenous vein with stripping. Option C. Deep venous thrombosis is managed primarily with anticoagulants and not operative procedure Option D. Diabetic foot treatment requires debridement and dressing.

questions.text: Perforator which is present around knee joint is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Named Perforators in our Body are as follows :

questions.text: Bisgard treatment is for:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Treatment for Venous Ulcer :Bisgaard Method:- To reduce edema, increase venous drainage, so as to promote ulcer healing. It consist of: 1. Elevation 2. Massage of the indurated area and whole calf 3. Passive and active exercise. 4. Care of the ulcer by regular cleaning with povidone iodine + H2O2, Dressing with EUSOL. 5. Antibiotics depending on culture sensitivity. 6. Skin graft after ulcer granulates. Option A. Arterial ulcers are trophic ulcers and require flap repair in most of cases Option C. Thromboangiitis obliterans is a PVD and is treated with drugs, Lumbar sympathectomy and bypass procedures. Option D. Raynaud's phenomenon is treated with drugs like CCB and Nitrates.

questions.text: Procedure shown in the following figure is used in the treatment of ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) SEPS: It stands for Subfascial Endoscopic Perforator Surgery . It is used to ligate the perforators in the subfascial ligation and thus treat the cause of varicose veins and venous ulcers. Option A , Operative procedure for varicose vein is trendelenburg's operation. Trendelenburg's operation consists of subfascial ligation of the saphenous vein with stripping. Option C. Deep venous thrombosis is managed primarily with anticoagulants and not operative procedure Option D. Fogarty catheter is used for the treatment of arterial thrombosis.

questions.text: Lipodermatosclerosis is most commonly seen on ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lipodermatosclerosis refers to changes in the skin of the lower legs. It is a form of panniculitis (inflammation of the layer of fat under the skin). Signs and symptoms include pain, hardening of skin, change in skin color (redness), swelling, and tapering of the legs above the ankles. It is associated with varicose vein so it is most commonly present on medial aspect of the legs. Lipodermatosclerosis on medial aspect of Leg.

questions.text: Contraindication for surgery of Varicose vein is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Wherever we are considering an operative intervention in a patient of varicose vein we need to rule out DVT . In patients of DVT due to the disease process there is destruction of the valves. If we perform a varicose vein surgery in patients of DVT. They might land up into venous gangrene. Other Contraindication: • Venous outflow obstruction and during pregnancy.

questions.text: Klippel trenaunay syndrome is associated with all of the following except ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Klippel–Trénaunay syndrome formerly Klippel–Trénaunay–Weber syndrome is a rare congenital medical condition in which blood vessels and/or lymph vessels fail to form properly. The three main features are nevus flammeus (port-wine stain), venous and lymphatic malformations, and soft-tissue hypertrophy of the affected limb. The classical triad of Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome consists of: vascular malformations of the capillary, venous and lymphatic vessels; varicosities of unusual distribution, particularly the lateral venous anomaly; and unilateral soft and skeletal tissue hypertrophy, usually the lower extremity.

questions.text: Pulsatile varicose vein in young adults is due to ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pulsatile varicose vein is a feature of AV Fistula.

questions.text: Most common cause of superficial thrombophlebitis is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) IV Cannula is the most common cause of superficial thrombophlebitis. Option C. Pancreatic Ca can also lead to superficial thrombophlebitis , it leads to migratory thrombophlebitis and is referred to as Trousseau's syndrome.

questions.text: May thurner or cockett syndrome involves:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) May thurner Syndrome:-Occurs due to compression of left iliac vein by overriding right iliac artery. It result in left iliofemoral deep vein thrombosis Nutcracker syndrome refers to compression of the left renal vein between the aorta and superior mesenteric artery.

choices.text: Transmitted pressure wave on coughing in a varicose vein
Related to the use of venous filling after emptying a length of vein

questions.text: Harvey Sign is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Venous refilling (Harvey's sign)— empty a segment of vein with two fingers distal finger is released to look for the timing of venous refilling Poor in ischamic limb and increased in arteriovenous fistula. This is known as HARVEY'S SIGN
